Generally bridges are built to connect two locations. For example, near where I used to live it has long been proposed that there be a bridge across Morecambe Bay, linking the old shipyard town of Barrow with the M6 motorway, hence opening the extremely deprived Cumbrian coast to development and investment. In that instance the bridge would benefit hundreds of thousands of people. I imagine there are similar instance in the US. The problem with tax cuts as a solution to the economic crisis is that they are extremely imprecise - you cannot control what the money is spent on, which means it may well be spent on Chinese imports from Walmart, which isn't a great boost to the US economy. Even worse, people will pay off credit cards and overdrafts, or save the money, effectively just adding to the already massive and pretty worthless bank bailouts. To take full advantage of the multiplier effects in the economy, money needs to be spent on infrastructure projects that will employ people in the short term and make the economy more efficient in the long term.
